makers.displaydate: born 1944, Anyako, Ghana; active Nsukka, Nigeria and Tema, Ghana
makers.displaymaker: El Anatsui, born 1944, Anyako, Ghana; active Nsukka, Nigeria and Tema, Ghana

texts.textentryhtml: El Anatsui first carved the wood planks he salvaged for this relief with a chainsaw, a tool that encouraged him toward abstraction and resonated with his investigation into the cultural and political violence of European colonialism. The flexibility of these planks provided the artist a surface with limitless opportunities on which to experiment with other woodworking power tools, including the blowtorch, wood drill, router, and band saw. Each tool enabled Anatsui to expand his formal vocabulary of sculptural, graphic, and design effects, merging references to Indigenous graphic systems from Nigeria like uli and nsibidi with the patterns found in textile traditions from Ghana, including adinkra and kente. The router, for example, allowed him to “draw,” rather than carve, more organic, bold, and linear forms, which he blackened and accentuated with a hot iron.
Artist studio, Nsukka, Nigeria; purchased by Janet Stanley, Washington, DC, in Nsukka, Nigeria, May 2, 1990; donated to the Princeton University Art Museum, Princeton, NJ, 2023.
